Package generation

Interface Maze

All Known Implementing Classes:
MazeContainer
public interface Maze
A Maze encapsulates all relevant information about a maze that can be explored in a game. A maze has finite dimensions width and height. It has a floor plan that represents where walls are with discrete integer locations in width and height range. It has information about the distance to the exit position from any location inside the maze. It carries information about the starting position.
Author:
pk

    • setMazedists

      void setMazedists​(Distance mazedists)
      Sets the distance values towards the exit for this maze. Note that the dimensions of the distance matrix needs to match with the cells.
      Parameters:
      mazedists - the distances to set

    • isValidPosition

      boolean isValidPosition​(int x, int y)
      Tells if (x,y) coordinate is within range.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      Returns:
      true if 0 <= x < width, 0 <= y < height

    • isInRoom

      boolean isInRoom​(int x, int y)
      Tells if the given position is inside a room.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      Returns:
      true if (x,y) position resides in an area marked as a room, false otherwise

    • getDistanceToExit

      int getDistanceToExit​(int x, int y)
      Tells how many steps it is from the given (x,y) coordinate to the exit position.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      Returns:
      the length of path to the exit

    • getPercentageForDistanceToExit

      float getPercentageForDistanceToExit​(int x, int y)
      Calculates a distance to exit as a percentage. 1.0 is for the starting position as this is the maximal distance possible.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      Returns:
      a value between 0.0 and 1.0, the smaller the closer

    • hasWall

      boolean hasWall​(int x, int y, CardinalDirection dir)
      Tells if one faces a wallboard at position (x,y) looking into the given direction. Note that the cardinal direction is absolute and not relative to the current direction such as right or left.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      dir - is the direction in terms of North, East, South, West
      Returns:
      true if (x,y) is valid and there is a wallboard in the given direction, false otherwise

    • isFacingDeadEnd

      boolean isFacingDeadEnd​(int x, int y, CardinalDirection cd)
      Checks if the given position and direction faces a dead end
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      cd - is a direction
      Returns:
      true if at the given position there is a wall to the left, right and front, false otherwise

    • getNeighborCloserToExit

      int[] getNeighborCloserToExit​(int x, int y)
      Provides coordinates of a position adjacent to the given (x,y) position that has a distance to the exit that is less than the distance for the given (x,y) position and there is also no wall between the given position and the adjacent one. For a maze that has a path from the any given position to the exit, any position other than the exit position itself must have an adjacent position that is closer. So with the exception of the exit position, existence of such a neighbor is guaranteed for any position. However, the neighbor need not be unique. One can imanine situations where more than one neighbor would have the same distance to the exit and this method would have to pick one.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height
      Returns:
      int array of length 2 with (x',y') coordinates for neighbor if exists, null otherwise

    • getStartingPosition

      int[] getStartingPosition()
      Provides coordinates (x,y) of the starting position for this maze. Maze generation algorithms are expected to use the position that is the farthest away from the exit as the starting position, i.e., the one with the maximum distance.
      Returns:
      the starting position

    • setStartingPosition

      void setStartingPosition​(int x, int y)
      Sets coordinates (x,y) of the starting position for this maze. Maze generation algorithms are expected to use the position that is the farthest away from the exit as the starting position, i.e., the one with the maximum distance.
      Parameters:
      x - is on the horizontal axis, 0 <= x < width
      y - is on the vertical axis, 0 <= y < height

    • getExitPosition

      int[] getExitPosition()
      Provides coordinates (x,y) of the exit position for this maze. This position is still inside the maze but at the very cell that has the an opening at one of its sides that leads to the outside of the maze. This position is called exit position. It is unique and its distance to the exit has a value of 1.
      Returns:
      the exit position
